history.subject: Math knowledge/skills retention
history.content:
This question is not really related to the course content, but I was just wondering if someone is not pursuing studies in mathematics, how much of the stuff we are learning right now will they retain? It just seems sad thinking that I'm probably gonna forget most of the stuff we're learning in 10, 15 years from now.

#pin

history.subject: Math knowledge/skills retention
history.content: This question is not really related to the course content, but I was just wondering if someone is not pursuing studies in mathematics, how much of the stuff we are learning right now will they retain? It just seems sad thinking that I'm probably gonna forget most of the stuff we're learning in 10, 15 years from now.

We tend to forget things we don't practice/use in our lives (unless you have a photographic memory). If this subject interests you, you can still pursue it as a hobby and that way you can retain most of the things while learning more. A thorough understanding of a concept inside out will still be well retained over long term. You may not have the exact formal definition but you know what it is (for example a derivative or integral).

It largely depends on what field you’re going in. Like if you’re going in a field where Maths is important (like my field is Physics, and Maths is quite important there), you’ll retain a lot more of the stuff we’ve learnt. But there is no general answer here. It will differ from person to person.

If you do not continue using math, you will probably forget a lot of the content quickly.  However, things that you have figured out yourself (as opposed to being told) will stay with you for a long time, and you will always be able to re-figure them out.

What will absolutely stay with you? Hopefully all the skills you have sharpened in the last eight months.  Resilience.  Persistence. Being comfortable taking on unknown problems.  Resourcefulness.  Drawing from what you know and figuring out how to adjust it to novel situations.  Understanding the difference between suspecting something is true and knowing is true because you have proven it.  Wanting to understand why things are true rather than memorizing answers, knowing how much more satisfying it is to understand, and that you are capable of it.  If you have experienced once the internal satisfaction of totally mastering and owning a concept inside out by yourself, through hard work, you will never be satisfied with less than that. 

In essence, what math is really about.

You know now that you are capable of much more than you thought possible if you are willing to embrace the struggle.  It is only through the struggle that you learn. Don't believe me? Look at the first problem set. Remember how you thought back them it was extremely difficult? Look at Tutorial #3. Remember how you thought back then it was impossible? If you look at them again now you will wonder what made them so intimidating.  That is how much you have grown, and it will stay with you. If MAT137 has done its job well, you are now a stronger, more resilient, more inquisitive, more audacious, and more persistent person than you were in September, and that will serve you good no matter what you choose to do in your future career, whether you become a mathematician, a programmer, a doctor, an entrepreneur, a politician, a teacher, or a farmer.  So who cares if you forget what the Maclaurin series of arctan is?  Embrace your newly-found powers.  Use them wisely.

children.subject:
I wholeheartedly agree with everything Alfonso said and I am confident it resonates with the entire teaching team. We all really believe in the skills you've gained during your time in MAT137.

For us (and hopefully you), the math is a delightful part of the journey.

I don't know if this is the answer you were looking for, but I remember thinking pretty much the same thing back when I took this course -- I found the material really, really cool, but I doubted it would ever be pertinent to what I was planning to study (actually, I was a humanities student!).

And now, it turns out that I can't imagine not studying math! So if you think you might miss the concepts or the problem sets or anything else about the course (and if you're asking this question, that's probably true!), I have a small suggestion for you: take a couple more math courses, and maybe you'll find yourself enjoying it all a little too much to leave behind so soon. :-)
Wait...Alyssa, so are you doing a maths specialist ?! (wow)
My program is the joint specialist in math and economics!

I agree with absolutely everything thus far posted. I wanted to also give my perspective, as a former student of this course, of what I believe the real lasting thing this course offers (as another former student), more than any specific mathematics:

Empowerment.

I notice that a lot of incoming MAT137 students (myself certainly included when I was in first year) do not have a huge amount of confidence that they even can DO things like prove theorems, find original solutions, and understand mathematical definitions. Some have even come to think that they are not "real math" kids like those perhaps in other courses / programs. Partially, I believe this is justifiably learned: high schools teach you to memorize solutions and apply rules blindly, without that key creative question of "why?", and tell you that this uncritical state is exactly where it is "useful" to be, in order to get good grades / get into university.

In this way, the key thing to learn in 137 is to UNLEARN this mathematical baggage: it is to directly ask for yourself "what do I really know?" and "why do I know it?", and, when failing to be able to answer this, to have the strength to find answers for yourself. This is what I took from this course, which I use every day in my primary discipline (Computer Science / Statistics), although I cannot imagine any academic discipline in which this kind of thinking isn't useful.

"If you have experienced once the internal satisfaction of totally mastering and owning a concept inside out by yourself, through hard work, you will never be satisfied with less than that."

I feel this.

history.subject: Playlist summary typos
history.content:
Dear all,

If you find any (suspected) typos in the Playlist summary document, please record them below in the "Follow Up Discussion".

It will help us keep track of them and make edits when we can. It will also help your fellow classmates in case they stumble across the same issue.

Thanks for your help!

Best,

Asif

children.subject: Small typo in Lagrange's remainder theorem (p. 46).
Noted and agreed. Thanks
Small detail but on page 21 video 6.11 definition of concavity, I think we should add 'or vice versa' to the very end.
also in page 24, video 7.5, to the end of the first line, I think we can add 'and P is a subset of [a, b]'

And also on page 24, video 7.5, definition of lower sum, upper sum, on the bottom line, it says 'infimum of f on [x_{i=1}, x_i] ...'. It should say 'infimum of f on [x_{i-1}, x_i] ...' Notice the = should be a -; the equals should be a minus sign.

Page 28, video 8.7, very last line.

It says 'inf'. I assume this should be the integral notation.

To the notes we can also add the other two 'notations of integral'

i) Definite Integral

and

iii) Function defined by an integral

On page 44, vide 14.3, there is a typo on the second line under the first derinition.

Assume is misspelt as Asum.

I am not too sure about this one:

On page 44, video 14.3, for the second definition, first line.

Should it say ... continuous functions at 0 instead of at a?
nevermind that last one is not an error
On the last page. Video 14.10, near the end, there is an exponent "m = 1", which I think should be "m-1"
Thanks for spotting all those! Much appreciated.
I believe this is a typo
Ah thanks. Well spotted.
I believe $$cosx$$ should be $$cosx = 1-\frac{x^2}{2!}+\frac{x^4}{4!}-\frac{x^6}{6!}+...$$
Thanks, Evan. Noted.

history.subject: LaTeX reference
history.content:
(This is a note from a former TA for this course named Charles.)

A great thing about this forum is that it supports a typesetting language called $$\LaTeX$$. This language renders beautiful mathematical equations making it much easier to read (In general, $$\LaTeX$$ is a good language to learn. Most formal academic papers are typesetted in $$\LaTeX$$. It just makes your work look so much more professional). If you surround your equations in double dollar signs, then anything between the dollar signs will be rendered in $$\LaTeX$$ format. The following is a reference for commonly used commands from last year's MAT137 Piazza forum, composed with the collective efforts of many students. To see the commands behind formatted expressions, right click the expression and click show math as TeX commands.

Feel free to add and edit this list. Please try to keep it relevant, clear, and concise for everyone's benefit. Log your changes in the discussion below.

CodeResult
Common Elements
a^{2} + b^{2} = c^{2}$$a^{2} + b^{2} = c^{2}$$
a_{n}x^{n} + a_{n-1}x^{n-1} + \ldots + a_{1}x + a_{0}$$a_{n}x^{n} + a_{n-1}x^{n-1} + \ldots + a_{1}x + a_{0}$$
f(x) = \frac{P(x)}{Q(x)}$$f(x) = \frac{P(x)}{Q(x)}$$
f(x) = \sqrt[n]{x}$$f(x) = \sqrt[n]{x}$$
x \geq y$$x \geq y$$
x \leq y$$x \leq y$$
x \gg y$$x \gg y$$
x \ll y$$x \ll y$$
\pm, \neq, \approx, \nless, \ngtr, \nleq, \ngeq, \infty, \cdot$$\pm, \neq, \approx, \nless, \ngtr, \nleq, \ngeq, \infty, \cdot$$

|x| = \left\{

\begin{array}{rl}

x & \text{ if } x \geq 0 \\

-x & \text{ if } x < 0

\end{array}

\right.

$$|x| = \left\{ \begin{array}{rl} x & \text{ if } x \geq 0 \\ -x & \text{ if } x < 0 \end{array} \right.$$

\delta(x)=

\begin{cases}

\infty & \text{if} x=0 \\

0 & \text{otherwise}

\end{cases}

$$\delta(x)=\begin{cases}<br/><br/>\infty & \text{if } x=0 \\<br/><br/>0 & \text{otherwise}<br/><br/>\end{cases}$$
\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{N}, \mathbb{Z}, \mathbb{Q}$$\mathbb{R}$$, $$\mathbb{N}$$, $$\mathbb{Z}$$, $$\mathbb{Q}$$
f = g \circ h$$f = g \circ h$$
\blacksquare$$\blacksquare$$
Automatically sized braces
\left( x^2 + 1 \right)$$\left( x^2 + 1 \right)$$
\left( \frac{1}{\left( x^2 + 1 \right)} \right)$$\left( \frac{1}{\left( x^2 + 1 \right)} \right)$$
\left[ \frac{1}{\left( x^2 + 1 \right)} \right]$$\left[ \frac{1}{\left( x^2 + 1 \right)} \right]$$
Logic
P \wedge Q$$P \wedge Q$$
P \vee Q$$P \vee Q$$
\neg{P} \vee Q$$\neg{P} \vee Q$$
P \implies Q$$P \implies Q$$
P \iff Q$$P \iff Q$$
Limits
\lim_{x \to c} f(x) = L$$\lim_{x \to c} f(x) = L$$
\lim\limits_{x \to c} f(x) = L$$\lim\limits_{x \to c} f(x) = L$$
\forall \epsilon > 0, \exists \delta > 0, …$$\forall\epsilon > 0, \exists\delta > 0, \ldots$$
0 < |x - c| < \delta \implies |f(x) - L| < 0$$0 < |x - c| < \delta \implies |f(x) - L| < 0$$
Trig Functions
\sin{x}, \cos{x}, \tan^a{x}$$\sin{x}, \cos{x}, \tan^a{x}$$
\csc{x}, \sec{x}, \cot^b{x}$$\csc{x}, \sec{x}, \cot^b{x}$$
Sets

a \in A

$$a\in A$$

a \notin A

$$a\notin A$$

\{ x\in\mathbb{R} : x\geq x^2\}

$$\{x\in\mathbb{R}:x\geq x^2\}$$

\cup_{i \in I} A_{i},\bigcup_{i \in I} A_{i}

$$\cup_{i \in I} A_{i},\bigcup_{i \in I} A_{i}$$

\cap_{i \in I} A_{i},\bigcap_{i \in I} A_{i}

$$\cap_{i \in I} A_{i},\bigcap_{i \in I} A_{i}$$

\subset, \not\subset, \subseteq, \nsubseteq

$$\subset, \not\subset, \subseteq, \nsubseteq$$

\mathbb{R} \setminus \mathbb{Q}

$$\mathbb{R} \setminus \mathbb{Q}$$
Integrals
U_{f}(P) = U_{f}(P) = \sum\limits_{i=1}^{|P|-1} \left[\sup_{x \in [x_i, x_{i+1}]}f(x)\right](x_{i+1} - x_i)$$U_{f}(P) = \sum\limits_{i=1}^{|P|-1} \left[\sup_{x \in [x_i, x_{i+1}]}f(x)\right](x_{i+1} - x_i)$$
L_{f}(P) = U_{f}(P) = \sum\limits_{i=1}^{|P|-1} \left[\inf_{x \in [x_i, x_{i+1}]}f(x)\right](x_{i+1} - x_i)$$L_{f}(P) = \sum\limits_{i=1}^{|P|-1} \left[\inf_{x \in [x_i, x_{i+1}]}f(x)\right](x_{i+1} - x_i)$$
\underline{I}_{a}^{b} = \sup_{P} L_{f}(P)$$\underline{I}_{a}^{b} = \sup_{P} L_{f}(P)$$
\overline{I}_{a}^{b} = \inf_{P} U_{f}(P)$$\overline{I}_{a}^{b} = \inf_{P} U_{f}(P)$$
\int_{a}^{b} f(s) \, ds$$\int_{a}^{b} f(s) \, ds$$
F(x) = \int_{a}^{x} f(s) \, ds$$F(x) = \int_{a}^{x} f(s) \, ds$$
\int f(s) \, ds, \displaystyle{ \int f(s) \, ds }$$\int f(s) \, ds$$, $$\displaystyle{ \int f(s) \, ds }$$
Other Mathematical Concepts
\sum\limits_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n^2}=\frac{\pi^2}{6}$$\sum\limits_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n^2}=\frac{\pi^2}{6}$$
Advanced Usage
\dfrac{P(x)}{Q(x)} = \tfrac{P(x)}{Q(x)}$$\dfrac{P(x)}{Q(x)} = \tfrac{P(x)}{Q(x)}$$
\textbf{Constant Value}$$\textbf{Constant Value}$$

history.subject: Another Good Question? (Still Bored...)
history.content:
Consider $$\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{\sin(n)}{n}$$.

a) Show that this series converges.

b) Compute the value this sum converges to.

Hint: You don't require FS to solve Part (a) or Part (b). If you don't want to use FS for Part (b), you'll have to introduce the complex expansion of $$\sin$$.

history.subject: Questions about summer classes
history.content: Good evening. I have a question. I will take two courses on summer school but they have time conflicts. Do we have replay for the online classes? Like the video you can go over again. Because I checked on acorn, there is no any other time for both the courses. Thanks, take care.

The answer to your question will depend on the class you are taking. If you go on the UofT timetable website and search for your desired course, you should be able to see specific instructions regarding the course. Some courses are synchronous (not recorded and live) while others are assynchronus (recorded). There's also some hybrid courses but I'm not too sure what that means.

children.subject:
From what I've heard, the "hybrid courses" are those that have a combination of recorded and live sessions. For example, tutorials might be live so you have to be present at a specific time (especially if there's a participation grade in the course) while lectures might be recorded (so you can watch or re-watch at your convenience). This information should probably be provided to you on the first day of classes in the syllabus!

Good luck with your classes!

history.subject: Final Mark
history.content: Hi, I wonder when can we get our marks back for the final? Thanks in advance.

children.subject: So how's the grading so far?
Be patient. Professors and teaching assistants are humans, too! You can't expect them to be grading machines, working day and night without rest.

history.content:
Grading final exams takes longer than normal term tests and then we must carefully submit final grades. We are following standard Faculty of Arts and Science procedure: first final grades will be submitted, and then your final exam will be released afterwards. I'll share more details on this and viewing your final after we submit grades. Please wait for those instructions.

This whole process always takes a while and this year has unique challenges. As has been said before @1925, there are several steps even after instructors finish so it will still be a while (about a week or more) before you see your final grade on ACORN.

Please continue to be patient. Thank you.

history.subject: A short question about the recent email.
history.content: The recent email said, " I will be hiring through the Work Study program, which means you must be a student in the Summer in order to apply. ". Am I considered as a student if I don't enroll in any courses in the summer?
I don't think so. Otherwise, all of us would qualify and the statement would be redundant.

The student answer is correct, the work study program requires an enrolment in courses over the summer to apply.

See the following for details: https://future.utoronto.ca/finances/financial-aid/work-study-program/

history.subject: General Question
history.content: How helpful is MAT224 with MAT237/257 (I already did MAT223 last semester)?

history.subject: General Question
history.content: How helpful is MAT224 with MAT237/257 (I already did MAT223 in last semester)?

MAT224 essentially generalizes what you learn in 223. As far as 237 goes, I don't think 224 is really needed to understand the calculus content. That being said, 224 was one of my favourite courses of all time and if I recall correctly, you're in physics? 224 definitely helps with understanding the mathematical formulation of quantum mechanics. I'd definitely recommend it.

Sounds good! Thanks a lot for the guidance. Really appreciate it!

(And yeah, I'm in Physics.)

history.subject: Some Good Questions (if you're bored - like me)
history.content:
I came across a series of questions a couple of days ago. I thought I'd share.

The last one is particularly interesting. It has both an elegant and an unnecessarily long solution. Do give it a go!

1) Let $$a_n, b_n$$ be sequences s.t. $$\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n$$ and $$\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} b_n$$ converge.

Is it possible for $$\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n \cdot b_n$$ to diverge?

(Answered Below)

2) Let $$a_n$$ be a positive sequence s.t. $$\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n < \infty$$.

Prove that $$\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{\sqrt{a_n}}{n}<\infty$$.

Hint: Viktor may have done this question in a line or two.

(Refer to the Cauchy-Shwartz Inequality, also known as the (Viktor) Bunyakovsky Inequality.)

children.subject:
For 1), let $$a_n = \frac{(-1)^{n}}{\sqrt{n}}$$ and $$b_n = \frac{(-1)^{n}}{\sqrt{n}}$$. The individual series converge while the series of products is the harmonic series

But if you force one of the sequences to be positive (A stronger condition), then the series of products must converge
Yes and Yes.
Actually, you don't even need one sequence to be positive, as long as its absolutely convergent the series of products converges
*As long one series is absolutely convergent
For 2), is $$N$$ any real number?
My bad. Just edited it.
Haha no worries.
For 2), I haven't written down the entire proof but I think you can use Cauchy condensation test
Interesting! I personally have another method in mind.

Since $$\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n$$ converges, $$\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} a_{2^n}$$  converges, hence by the BCT, $$\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \sqrt{a_{2^n}}$$ converges. So by the Cauchy condensation test, our desired series converges
I'm not sure if this justification works. What happens if $$a_n = \frac{1}{n^2}$$?
Oh yeah there's a mistake there lemme think again

You'd still have to deal with the $$n$$ in the denominator. But that won't be a big issue I guess.

PS. There is an easier method.
For question2, for n large enough, the square root of a_n / n < a_n / n < a_n, Then appy BCT?
Does this work with $$a_n = \frac{1}{n^2}$$?

I think I know how to do it now, wait for me to write it

It is indeed pretty short

Interpret $$\frac{\sqrt{a_n}}{n}$$ as the geometric mean of $$a_n$$ and $$\frac{1}{n^2}$$, now there's a pretty famous inequality where the geometric mean is no greater than the arithmetic mean. The arithmetic mean is one half of $$a_n + \frac{1}{n^2}$$, and it is clear that the series of arithmetic means is convergent (Split it into two parts). Therefore the series of geometric means converges, and so our desired series converges
Interesting. The solution I have in mind is using the Cauchy-Schwartz Inequality.

Ah ok yeah that's a good one too, that inequality is quite important in math I think

What does the really long solution use?

children.subject: I can't explain why 6.d is true but for 6.a consider sin(n)/n
Should all terms be positive?
Sorry! I was thinking of sin^2(n)/n my bad
One of the conditions to use BCT is the terms for both series are positive. an is positive for sure from the question. But the terms of the series (sinn)an is not always positive.

It doesn't matter. The condition which stipulates a series being strictly positive is to ensure the biconditional holds.

If the series isn't strictly greater than 0, a conclusion can still be made. Recall the Extended LCT. That should help.
I was curious why is 6c false? Should it not be true ?
Consider $$\displaystyle{\sum_n^\infty \frac{1}{n\ln n}}$$.

The above is a counterexample, but it's important that you examine why you think it should be true. 

Or rather, you shouldn't think it's true unless you have a justification. So what's the justification? State it and examine it closely to determine whether it's valid.

history.content:
The example above is good, but I would suggest not thinking about it terms of that specific counterexample. 

The limit assumption means the terms get closer and closer to 0. Why do you believe that should imply that it's eventually decreasing? The sequence can go up and down but still get closer to zero.

history.subject: Q10 Inflection points on final exam
history.content: On the solutions for the final exam Q10, 4 is included as an inflection point, but I thought that a function must be differentiable at its inflection points according to the videos. Is this an error or have I interpreted the videos wrong?

children.subject: The poster is correct, in the vid 6.11, 6:35 it clearly states that f is in fact at least once differentiable on some interval I, and the inflection point is interior to I, thus f is also once differentiable at the inflection point!
According to the definition in the videos, you're correct.

<md>
The function could behave like $$x^{(1/3)}$$ near that point.
</md>
Yes but by definition given in the videos, that's not an inflection point!

<md>
You are right by the videos, but whoever made the solutions must have considered this an inflection point.
</md>

history.content:
This is a controversial issue. (Honestly speaking, I knew this will end up being controversial the moment I saw the question).

I personally believe $$x=4$$ should be an inflection point, although, given the definition in the videos, I decided against putting it in my answer as well.

I wrote a detailed comment about this issue earlier. I'll copy paste it here: (@764)

-----------------------------------------

This a very good question.

I'll answer your question based on two different interpretations.

Unfortunately, both interpretations produce contrary results, and I'm not certain exactly which interpretation is correct.

I'd recommend you also ask a Professor or a TA.

INTERPRETATION 1

i) $$f(x)$$ isn't differentiable at $$x=c$$, i.e. $$\forall \delta >0, \forall x \in \mathbb{R}, x \in (c-\delta , c + \delta) \Rightarrow f'(x)$$ DNE.

If you search up the definition of an 'Inflection Point', or refer to Video 6.11 (8:22), you'll deduce that:

“A point of inflection is a point c in the interior of the domain of a differentiable function (i.e., the function is defined and differentiable on an open interval containing that point) such that the function is concave in one sense to the immediate left of c and concave in the other sense to the immediate right of c.”

Based on this definition, if $$f(x)$$ isn't differentiable at $$x=c$$, then $$x=c$$ cannot be a Point of Inflection.

For example: $$f(x)=x^{\frac{1}{3}}$$. This function changes concavity at $$x=0$$, but isn't differentiable at $$x=0$$. Hence, based on this definition, $$(0,0)$$ is not an Inflection Point.

Why? Well, the idea is that a Point of Inflection corresponds to a 'Local Extrema' on the 'First Derivative Graph'. If $$f(x)$$ isn't differentiable at $$x=c$$, then the First Derivative Graph cannot possibly have a 'Local Extrema' at $$x=c$$.

ii) $$f(x)$$ is differentiable at $$x=c$$, but $$f''(c)$$ isn't defined, i.e. $$f(x)$$ isn't twice differentiable at any interval centered at $$x=c$$.

For example: $$f(x)=\left\{\begin{matrix}x^2 & x<0\\ -x^2 & x \geq 0 \end{matrix}\right.$$

In this case, $$(0,0)$$ is an Inflection Point. Moreover, at $$(0,0)$$, $$f'(x)$$ has a local maximum. Additionally, $$f(x)$$ changes concavity at $$x=0$$. However, $$f''(0)$$ isn't defined.

Nevertheless, $$(0,0)$$ is an Inflection Point.

INTERPRETATION 2

That said, in highschool, I studied that $$x=c$$ is an inflection point as long as $$f''(c)=0$$ or DNE, and $$f''(c)$$ changes signs as it crosses $$x=c$$.

Under this interpretation, $$f(x)=x^{\frac{1}{3}}$$ has a Point of Inflection at $$(0,0)$$.

(Added: In general, this definition implies that $$x=c$$ is a Point of Inflection if and only if the function changes concavity and is continuous about $$x=c$$, thus not requiring differentiability anymore.)

-----------------------------------------

To put it all together, if you strictly go by the definitions in the videos, I don't believe $$x=4$$ is an inflection point. That said, a lot of people, on the basis of other acceptable definitions, argue that a given point is a 'Point of Inflection' as long as the function changes concavity and is continuous about a given point, i.e. implying that the existence of a vertical tangent line is allowed at a Point of Inflection, something not allowed by the definition in the videos. 

(Personally, I like the definition which only requires a change in concavity and continuity. It just makes more sense.)

This is a controversial issue. I personally believe $$x=4$$ should be an inflection point, although, given the definition in the videos, I decided against putting it in my answer as well.

That said, a lot of people, on the basis of other acceptable definitions, argue that a given point is a 'Point of Inflection' as long as the function changes concavity and is continuous about a given point, i.e. implying that the existence of a vertical tangent line is allowed at a Point of Inflection, something not allowed by the definition in the videos. 

(Personally, I like the definition which only requires a change in concavity and continuity. It just makes more sense.)

This is a controversial issue. I personally believe $$x=4$$ should be an inflection point, although, given the definition in the videos, I decided against putting it in my answer as well.

I wrote a detailed comment about this issue earlier. I'll copy paste it here: (@764)

-----------------------------------------

This a very good question.

I'll answer your question based on two different interpretations.

Unfortunately, both interpretations produce contrary results, and I'm not certain exactly which interpretation is correct.

I'd recommend you also ask a Professor or a TA.

INTERPRETATION 1

i) $$f(x)$$ isn't differentiable at $$x=c$$, i.e. $$\forall \delta >0, \forall x \in \mathbb{R}, x \in (c-\delta , c + \delta) \Rightarrow f'(x)$$ DNE.

If you search up the definition of an 'Inflection Point', or refer to Video 6.11 (8:22), you'll deduce that:

“A point of inflection is a point c in the interior of the domain of a differentiable function (i.e., the function is defined and differentiable on an open interval containing that point) such that the function is concave in one sense to the immediate left of c and concave in the other sense to the immediate right of c.”

Based on this definition, if $$f(x)$$ isn't differentiable at $$x=c$$, then $$x=c$$ cannot be a Point of Inflection.

For example: $$f(x)=x^{\frac{1}{3}}$$. This function changes concavity at $$x=0$$, but isn't differentiable at $$x=0$$. Hence, based on this definition, $$(0,0)$$ is not an Inflection Point.

Why? Well, the idea is that a Point of Inflection corresponds to a 'Local Extrema' on the 'First Derivative Graph'. If $$f(x)$$ isn't differentiable at $$x=c$$, then the First Derivative Graph cannot possibly have a 'Local Extrema' at $$x=c$$.

ii) $$f(x)$$ is differentiable at $$x=c$$, but $$f''(c)$$ isn't defined, i.e. $$f(x)$$ isn't twice differentiable at any interval centered at $$x=c$$.

For example: $$f(x)=\left\{\begin{matrix}x^2 & x<0\\ -x^2 & x \geq 0 \end{matrix}\right.$$

In this case, $$(0,0)$$ is an Inflection Point. Moreover, at $$(0,0)$$, $$f'(x)$$ has a local maximum. Additionally, $$f(x)$$ changes concavity at $$x=0$$. However, $$f''(0)$$ isn't defined.

Nevertheless, $$(0,0)$$ is an Inflection Point.

INTERPRETATION 2

That said, in highschool, I studied that $$x=c$$ is an inflection point as long as $$f''(c)=0$$ or DNE, and $$f''(c)$$ changes signs as it crosses $$x=c$$.

Under this interpretation, $$f(x)=x^{\frac{1}{3}}$$ has a Point of Inflection at $$(0,0)$$.

-----------------------------------------

To put it all together, if you strictly go by the definitions in the videos, I don't believe $$x=4$$ is an inflection point. That said, a lot of people, on the basis of other acceptable definitions, argue that a given point is a 'Point of Inflection' as long as the function changes concavity and is continuous about a given point, i.e. implying that the existence of a vertical tangent line is allowed at a Point of Inflection, something not allowed by the definition in the videos. 

(Personally, I like the definition which only requires a change in concavity and continuity. It just makes more sense.)

We'll accept either answer for $$x=4$$.

According to the videos, it's not an inflection point.

According to most widely-accepted definitions, it is an inflection point.

The above discussion is very good. I just want to comment on the original question regarding the possible equivalence of two statements.

In general, if two statements are nearly identical but one has some "extra" information (here: one statement says something about the behaviour of $$f$$ exactly at $$a$$ and the other doesn't), you should be pretty skeptical. Think about it this way: we have equivalence if both statements imply the other. A stronger condition should probably imply a weaker condition, but the converse is often false. For the equivalence to hold, you'd likely have to justify that the extra information is superfluous and doesn't change the meaning of the statement. So, here it could be a good idea to see whether imposing the extra condition on $$f$$ at $$a$$ affects the premise of the statement. See if you can find some examples that fit one definition and not the other! Another good strategy could be to describe both statements in words, and to see if the descriptions match up (that's also a good way to check if you understand the statement well).

Another function for you to consider:

$$ f(x)=\left\{ \begin{array}{ll} \pi & x \neq 0 \\ 42 & x=0 \end{array} \right. $$

Does this help?

PS: The steps I outlined above won't immediately give the answer 100% of the time, but they could be a reasonable first approach when you're working on a question like this.

history.subject: Q5 Final
history.content: Why is the answer for Q5 D instead of C?? How can we find lim x->0 f(x) just from the question?

Here's the basic idea:

$$\lim_{x\rightarrow 0} \frac{x^2}{f(x)}= 7 \Rightarrow \lim_{x\rightarrow 0} \frac{f(x)}{x^2}= \frac{1}{7}$$

Then, by the Limit Law of Products,

$$\lim_{x\rightarrow 0} f(x) = \lim_{x\rightarrow 0} (\frac{f(x)}{x^2} \cdot x^2) =\lim_{x\rightarrow 0} (\frac{f(x)}{x^2}) \cdot \lim_{x\rightarrow 0} (x^2) = \frac{1}{7} \cdot 0 = 0$$

Here's the basic idea:

$$\lim_{x\rightarrow 0} \frac{x^2}{f(x)}= 7 \Rightarrow \lim_{x\rightarrow 0} \frac{f(x)}{x^2}= \frac{1}{7}$$

Then, by the Limit Law of Products,

$$\lim_{x\rightarrow 0} f(x) = \lim_{x\rightarrow 0} (\frac{f(x)}{x^2} \cdot x^2) =\lim_{x\rightarrow 0} (\frac{f(x)}{x^2}) \cdot \lim_{x\rightarrow 0} (x^2) = \frac{1}{7} \cdot 0 = 0$$
The assumption implies that the limit has to equal zero.

Question 2 and 8 from the exam are valid because they are definite integrals with respect to $$t$$. 

Think about it this way:

if you plug in, say, 3 into the functions, you'd get

$$ B(3)=\int_{0}^{3} \frac{t}{1+3^8} dt $$

and

$$ V(3)=\int_{0}^{3} (\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{(3t^2)^n}{n!}) dt $$

both of which are perfectly valid integrals

Question 2 and 8 from the exam are valid because they are definite integrals with respect to $$t$$. 

Think about it this way:

if you plug in, say, 3 into the functions, you'd get

$$ B(3)=\int_{0}^{3} \frac{t}{1+3^8} dt $$

or 

$$ V(3)=\int_{0}^{3} (\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{(3t^2)^n}{n!}) dt $$

both of which are perfectly valid integrals

Question 2 and 8 from the exam are valid because they are definite integrals with respect to $$t$$. 

Think about it this way:

if you plug in, say, 3 into $$F(x)$$, you'd get

$$ F(3)=\int_{0}^{3} \frac{t}{1+3^8} dt $$

or 

$$ F(3)=\int_{0}^{3} (\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{(3t^2)^n}{n!}) dt $$

both of which are perfectly valid integrals. This is also true for any other real values you plug in within their respective domains.

Question 2 and 8 from the exam are valid because they are definite integrals with respect to $$t$$. 

Think about it this way: if you plug in, say, 3 into $$F(x)$$, you'd get:

$$ F(3)=\int_{0}^{3} \frac{t}{1+3^8} dt $$

or 

$$ F(3)=\int_{0}^{3} (\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{(3t^2)^n}{n!}) dt $$

both of which are perfectly valid integrals. This is also true for any other real values you plug in within their respective domains.

You can think of the variable of integration as a dummy, similar to the index of summation when you write a sum in sigma notation. In a sum (as with an integral), it is not wrong to have a variable and an the index-dummy -- they just serve different purposes. For example, if you're integrating with respect to $$t$$, this $$t$$ has no meaning outside of the integral, so using it as a bound of integration is a problem. But, as is the case with Taylor Series, the presence of another variable is not a problem a priori. As long as you don't conflate the purpose of the variables, you are free to use both!

history.content:
Can anyone explain why question 6c was false?

I thought that 1/n was like the 'middle point', where values smaller than it converged, and values larger than it diverged, like the p series. So since this a sum of positive terms, which are decreasing, and each is smaller than this 'threshold', shouldn't it converge?

Thanks

I will once again bring up this counterexample: $$\displaystyle{\sum_n^\infty \frac{1}{n\ln n}}$$. While the question does try to suggest that it should be treated as some sort of "middle ground", this is exactly the question you should be asking when you see this: is this some sort of middle point, or not?

It's usually a better idea to assume false until you can come up with a good reason as to why it's true. These questions may not always appeal to your intuition.

$$\frac{1}{n}$$ is the middle point in the set of so-called $$p$$-series, but there are lots of other series. 

In fact, here's a nice exercise, which demonstrates that there is no "dividing line" among growth rates for convergent and divergent series 

Let $$\{a_n\}$$ and $$\{b_n\}$$ be sequences. Assume $$\sum a_n$$ diverges and $$\sum b_n$$ converges. Assume to make it interesting that both sequences limit to zero. 

Find new two sequences

  • $$\{c_n\}$$, such that $$\sum c_n$$ diverges but $$c_n$$ goes to zero faster than $$a_n$$, in the sense that $$\lim\limits_{n \to \infty} \dfrac{c_n}{a_n} = 0$$. 
  • $$\{d_n\}$$, such that $$\sum d_n$$ converges but $$d_n$$ goes to zero slower than $$b_n$$, in the sense that $$\lim\limits_{n \to \infty} \dfrac{d_n}{b_n} = \infty$$.

    • $$\{d_n\}$$, such that $$\sum d_n$$ converges but $$d_n$$ goes to zero slower than $$b_n$$, in the sense that $$\lim\limits_{n \to \infty} \dfrac{d_n}{b_n} = \infty$$.

history.subject: Final question Q6b
history.content: What’s the difference between not decreasing and non-decreasing？

If you are asking about a function.

Let ƒ be a function defined on an interval I.

We can say the function is decreasing if ∀x, y ∈ I, x < y implies ƒ(x) > ƒ(y). (not decreasing is the negation of this, just try to negate this)

However, non-decreasing means that ∀x, y ∈ I, x < y implies ƒ(x) ≥ ƒ(y).

The conclusions for the sequence is almost the same.

If you are asking about a function.

Let ƒ be a function defined on an interval I.

We can say the function is decreasing if ∀x, y ∈ I, x < y implies ƒ(x) > ƒ(y). (not decreasing is the negation of this, just try to negate this)

However, non-decreasing means that ∀x, y ∈ I, x < y implies ƒ(x) ≥ ƒ(y)

Why don't you begin by stating the definitions of both of those things, and we'll go from there. We've told you the definition of non-decreasing, so you can just look that up. We've told you the definition of decreasing so you can negate it and come up with the definition of "not decreasing". 

Reply with your answers below and if you're still confused we can talk about them.
Why don't you begin by stating the definitions of both of those things, and we'll go from there.

children.subject: Even if you did't recall the definitions, you could've actually come up with the correct answer using the Monotone Convergence Theorem. In general, the MCT states that: "If a sequence is eventually monotonic and bounded, then it is convergent." There is a variant which states that: "If a sequence is decreasing and bounded below, then it is convergent." In the given question, the sequence is assumed to be positive. Thus, the sequence is clearly bounded below by 0. Then, if the sequence is decreasing, it must be convergent. However, we know the sequence isn't convergent, and, as such, the sequence must be non-decreasing (if it was decreasing, it would have converged).

history.subject: Optimization Question - bounding the domain
history.content:
Hi,

I wonder what determines if we should bound the domain of certain variables in an optimization question. For video 6.1, I wonder why we’re not bounding the domain of the dimension variables x and y when we’re told that the volume needs to be at most 500cm^3. I thought about it and realize that in this case there is really no bound in how big either variable can get (ex. y can be approaching 0 and x can get arbitrary big and still satisfy the equation of constraint of x^2y = 500. I’m not really sure, but does it depend on the equation of constraint? **Say if it involves a product/quotient(ex. 100 = xy) then no bounds, but if it involves a sum with variables separated (ex. 100 = x + y) then there is a bound. I’ll try to figure this out because sometimes it’s not very clear if we should bound the domain or not. 


*when I say bound I mean the upper bound
** assuming x and y both have a lower bound already

Thanks in advance!

This is usually a decision that you can make by looking at two things: the context of the question and the equations themselves.

Contextually, it might make sense for a variable to have some bounds even if the equations don't immediately suggest it (e.g., if you think back to the question about the cat's box from Test 3, the height of a box can't possibly be negative). As you described above, the constraints themselves might also imply bounds -- your two equations and the differences between them look great to me. (Indeed, if the product of two variables is a given constant, one variable can get very close to 0 and the other can get very large, and the best you can do is perhaps finding some lower bound. For addition, as you said, we often have an easier time bounding the variables.)

In short, your best bet for finding the bounds is just checking through all of the information you're given in the problem and verifying that what you're writing makes sense. Remember that not all optimization questions necessarily have two finite bounds for each variable, so please don't overthink the problems!

Hope this helps!

history.subject: Past final question
history.content: How would you go about solving this question and what exactly is the answer? (From 2019 past final exam)

The Rigorous Method: Taylor Series are unique. You can do a comparison of the coefficients with the standard formula for Taylor Series.

Non-Rigorous Method: Identify a Pattern.

Well I wouldn't want to tell you the exact answer, since then it wouldn't be a useful practice problem. Remember, the thing you're practicing is the methodology; if you can't detect errors in your process, you've sort of missed the point. 

As to your question, in principle this isn't any different to the other series evaluation questions you've seen. It's just that in those earlier problems you related the given series to the Taylor series for sine, cosine, the exponential, the geometric series, etc. In this case you'll relate the given series to the Taylor series for $$B$$. The main idea behind the question is to find the first non-zero term of the Taylor Series, suppose we call it CX^n where c is non-zero constant. Then think in this way, when you take nth derivative for the whole series and evaluate at 0, which means the CX^m where m < n will be zero also CX^L where L >n will also be zero. So f^(n)(0) = the coefficient of the nth term.

history.content: Can't seem to figure out what to do for this one. I factored the binomial, but I'm still stuck. I tried one method which involved using e^x^2, but in order to relate the two summations the work got very complicated, so I assume I am just missing something. Any help would be appreciated.

Hint:

Try to separate the series into 3 series ($$4n^2 + 8n + 3$$ into $$4n^2$$, $$8n$$ and $$3$$), then compute them separately.

The computation takes me a long time.

Hint:

Try to separate the series into 3 series ($$4n^2 + 8n + 3$$ into $$4n^2$$, $$8n$$ and $$3$$), then compute them separately.

Factoring the polynomial is an excellent idea; let's start with that: $$4n^2+8n+3=(2n+1)(2n+3)$$.

We probably get that from differentiating twice. (In general, it can be useful to remember that polynomial terms with $$n$$ in the numerator are often obtained via differentiation while similar terms in the denominator often come from integration--it's a reasonably common pattern.)

But it looks like we never differentiate when the general term has $$x^{2n+2}$$ -- otherwise we would have had $$(2n+2)$$ in the numerator, too... Can you see a way in which we can "skip" this one? 

 

---

A more general comment: After you pick the function you want to work with, you have three big tools at your disposal with these questions: differentiating, integrating, and multiplying/dividing by $$x$$ or a scalar. Your mission is to figure out how to use combinations of these operations so that you can get the terms you want!

children.subject: This is such a brilliant idea!!!
I'm very glad it helped!! (By the way, I didn't give much away in the hint -- so you did all the hardest parts of the question yourself!) :-)

Sorry, I'm still confused about what to do...

May I have more hints on this question?
Would you be able to post what you've tried so far, please? This would help me figure out what a helpful hint might be!

I think I should take derivative on $$\frac{\sqrt{x}^{2n+3}}{n!}$$ three times to get $$\frac{(2n+3)(2n+2)(2n+1)x^{2n}}{n!})$$. Then when I take x = $$\sqrt{2}$$, I can use the form of $$e^{\sqrt{2}}$$. But I don't know how to cancel the (2n+2) with denominator.
Oh, I wanted to show take derivative on $$\frac{x^{2n+3}}{n!}$$

There's nothing here that'll really help us cancel out a $$(2n+2)$$ (everything in the denominator looks like it comes directly from the Taylor Series of a certain function). Also, since we have a polynomial of degree 2 in the numerator, it's pretty likely that we only differentiated twice (not 3 times).

Instead, you should try to look for a way to "skip" differentiating when the exponents aren't what you'd like to worth with -- i.e., you want to differentiate only when you have $$x^{2n+3}$$ and $$x^{2n+1}$$ but not $$x^{2n+2}$$. Any ideas about how we could avoid differentiating when the general term has $$x^{2n+2}$$ in the first place?
Do you mean I can use sin(x)? But in that way, I even have no idea how to make it a similar form with the question...

What I did to skip differentiating the $$2n+2$$ is that I started with the Taylor series of $$xe^{x^2}$$, which is $$\displaystyle \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{x^{2n+1}}{n!}$$. I integrated it to get a $$2n+2$$ in the denominator and I multiplied by an extra $$x$$ to have $$x^{2n+3}$$ in the numerator. I then differentiated 3 times but the $$2n+2$$ in the numerator was cancelled by the one in the denominator.

The computation is really long and tedious and I'm not exactly sure if I this is the correct approach.
There's a much easier way. You can just begin by differentiating. There is a way to ensure $$2n+2$$ doesn't appear at all.
Ummm, what do you mean by "beginning by differentiating"? Should I begin with differentiating $$\frac{(4n^2+8n+3)2^n}{n!}$$?

If you're differentiating then integrating just to have things cancel out, there might be an easier approach to try! In particular, you want to do something so that you never have to differentiate a term with $$x^{2n+2}$$... perhaps it's a good time to try a technique other than integrating/differentiating? :-)

As for the use of $$\sin x$$, I would caution you against using functions whose Taylor Series have fundamental differences (e.g., is there an $$(-1)^n$$?) from the series you're working with... Is there a function that might be a better match?
Do you mean manipulating it algebraically?
Yes, that would be a good idea!
Maybe I can separate it into 4x^2, 8x, and 3, just like the student above said?
Or I can separate it into $$4(n-1)^22^n-2^n$$
Have you tried the hints I gave? If so, was perhaps there a step you got confused on?
Yes, I still don't know how to "skip" 2n+2...

The idea here is that we don't want to take a derivative of a term with $$x^{2n+2}. Other than derivatives or integrals, is there another technique you can try that would allow you to change the exponent?
I think I might have thought of how to do it, but I'm not sure if this is it. When you have the $$x^{2n+2}$$, divide the function by $$x$$ to get $$x^{2n + 1}$$ if that makes sense.
Just multiplying or dividing x?

That would be an excellent idea! Notice that multiplication/division by $$x$$ allows you to change only the exponent in the general term without affecting anything else. That might be very useful here! Can you see why?
Oh! I think I got it! Thank you Sooo much!
You're very welcome!

history.subject: Logarithm as a Power Series
history.content:
I have a question regarding Video 14.10 - Logarithm as a Power Series. In the video, it is stated that the power series expansion for $$\ln(1+x)$$ is valid for $$|x| < 1$$. However, when the power series for $$\ln(1+x)$$, which is $$\displaystyle \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} (-1)^n \frac{x^{n+1}}{n+1}$$, is evaluated at $$x = 1$$, the series will converge by the AST.

Therefore, shouldn't the power series expansion for $$\ln(1+x)$$ be valid for $$x \in (-1, 1]$$ instead of $$(-1, 1)$$. I feel like I might be missing something here, but I'm not sure what.

history.subject: Logarithm as a Power Series
history.content:
I have a question regarding Video 14.10 - Logarithm as a Power Series. In the video, it is stated that the power series expansion for $$\ln(1+x)$$ is valid for $$|x| < 1$$. However, when the power series for $$\ln(1+x)$$, which is $$\displaystyle \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} (-1)^n \frac{x^{n+1}}{n+1}$$, is evaluated at $$x = 1$$, the series will converge by the AST.

Therefore, shouldn't the power series expansion for $$\ln(1+x)$$ be valid for $$x \in (-1, 1]$$. I feel like I might be missing something here, but I'm not sure what.

You're right. That said, the issue is quite simple: $$x=1$$ is an endpoint. As you'll see later on (in upper years), endpoints of the intervals of convergence are somewhat annoying. We have a lot of Theorems which work nicely in the interior of the interval of convergence, but which do not apply to the endpoints. It is for this reason that we usually overlook what's happening at the endpoints.

The students' answer is correct. 

The series converges at $$x = 1$$, but that doesn't guarantee (in general) that the function equals the series there.

children.subject: That is also something I have trouble grasping. What is the difference between the interval of convergence of a Taylor series and the interval it is analytic on? Also, to prove that a function is analytic not only at a point but on its domain, we can do a similar proof but fix an arbitrary $$a$$ instead, correct?

There is a Theorem which you'll study later on (in Complex Analysis, I believe) which states that if a function is analytic at $$a$$, where $$a$$ is an interior point to the Interval of Convergence, then the function is also analytic everywhere on the interior of the Interval of Convergence of the Taylor Series cenetered at $$a$$ (i.e. it may or may not be analytic at the end-points). In general, the 'Interval of Convergence of a Taylor Series' and the 'Interval a Function is Analytic On' need not be the same.

As for your last question about proving a function is analytic on a given interval, in theory, it possible to fix an arbitrary constant $$a$$. However, this method is extremely tideous, and perhaps, practically impossible (just think about it, you'll have to determine a pattern for the derivative of a function at infinitely many different points, i.e. $$f'(a)$$ for any arbitrary $$a\in I$$). This is, in general, an inefficient way of proving a function is analytic on a given domain. An efficient way would be to show a function is analytic at $$a$$, where $$a$$ is an interior point to the Interval of Convergence of the Taylor Series, and then use the Theorem I stated above (after proving it of course) to conclude that the function is analytic everywhere in the interior of the Interval of Convergence of the Taylor Series centered at $$a$$.

Just to add to Mohid's answer, there's a nice counterexample in my lecture slides (find the lecture that talks about analytic functions). The example is a function that is not analytic at zero, but whose Taylor series centred at zero converges everywhere.

history.subject: Another Nice Proof - The Lagrange Remainder Theorem
history.content:
Well, due to the circumstances, I haven't been able to share any proofs (which, in case you haven't noticed, I like to do).

That said, I'm sharing a simple and pretty relevant proof. 

The Lagrange Remainder Theorem:

Theorem:

  • Let $$I$$ be an open interval. Let $$a\in I$$.
  • Let $$n\in \mathbb{N}$$.
  • Let $$f$$ be a $$C^{n+1}$$ function on $$I$$.
  • Let $$P_n(x)= \sum_{k=0}^{n} \frac{f^{(k)}(a)}{k!} (x-a)^k$$ be its $$n$$-th Taylor Polynomial.
  • Let $$R_n(x)=f(x)-P_n(x)$$ be the remainder.
  • Then,

$$\exists \xi \in (a,x), R_n(x)=\frac{f^{(n+1)}(\xi)}{(n+1)!} (x-a)^{n+1}$$

Proof: 

  • Let $$f$$ be a 'smooth curve' defined near $$a$$.
  • Then, using the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, $$\forall x$$ near $$0$$, I can write,

$$f(x)=f(a)+\int_{a}^{x} f'(t) dt$$

  • Use Integration By Parts: $$u=f'(t), du=f''(t)dt, dv=dt, v=t-x$$. Then,

$$f(x)=f(a)+[(t-x)f'(t)]_{t=a}^{t=x} - \int_{a}^{x} f''(t)(t-x)dt$$ 

$$\Rightarrow f(x)=f(a)+(x-a)f'(a) - \int_{a}^{x} f''(t)(t-x)dt$$ 

  • Use Integration By Parts: $$u=f''(t), du=f'''(t)dt, dv=(t-x)dt, v=\frac{(t-x)^2}{2}$$. Then,

$$\Rightarrow f(x)=f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)+ \frac{1}{2} f''(a) (x-a)^2 + \int_{a}^{x} \frac{1}{2} f'''(t) (t-x)^2 dt$$ 

  • After $$n$$ iterations, we get (can be shown rigorously using Induction),

$$f(x)=\sum_{i=0}^{n} \frac{f^{(i)} (a)}{i!} (x-a)^i + \int_{a}^{x} \frac{f^{(n+1)} (t)}{n!} (x-t)^n dt$$

  • The 'Remainder' is:

$$R_{n,a} = f(x)-P_{n,a} =\int_{a}^{x} \frac{f^{(n+1)} (t)}{n!} (x-t)^n dt$$

  • Note: This is the Integral Form of the Remainder.
  • Note: The steps I'm doing from here on can be replaced by the Integral Mean Value Theorem. I'll instead use the steps which are used to prove the IMVT itself.
  • Next, as $$f^{(n+1)}$$ is continuous, by the Extreme Value Theorem, it has both a Max and a Min.
  • Let $$M$$ be the Maximum and $$N$$ be the Minimum of $$f^{(n+1)}$$ on $$[a,x]$$.
  • Then,

$$N \leq f^{(n+1)}(t) \leq M$$

$$\Rightarrow N(x-t)^n \leq f^{(n+1)}(t)(x-t)^n \leq M(x-t)^n$$

$$\Rightarrow \int_{a}^{x} N(x-t)^n dt \leq \int_{a}^{x} f^{(n+1)}(t)(x-t)^n dt \leq \int_{a}^{x} M(x-t)^n dt$$

$$\Rightarrow N \frac{(x-a)^{n+1}}{n+1} \leq \int_{a}^{x} f^{(n+1)}(t)(x-t)^n dt \leq M \frac{(x-a)^{n+1}}{n+1}$$

$$\Rightarrow N \leq \frac{\int_{a}^{x} f^{(n+1)}(t)(x-t)^n dt}{\frac{(x-a)^{n+1}}{n+1}} \leq M $$

  • Then, by the Intermediate Value Theorem, as $$f^{(n+1)}$$ is continuous,

$$\exists \xi (a,x), f^{(n+1)}(\xi) = \frac{\int_{a}^{x} f^{(n+1)}(t)(x-t)^n dt}{\frac{(x-a)^{n+1}}{n+1}}$$

$$\Rightarrow \exists \xi (a,x), \frac{f^{(n+1)}(\xi)}{n+1}(x-a)^{n+1} = \int_{a}^{x} f^{(n+1)}(t)(x-t)^n dt$$

$$\Rightarrow \exists \xi (a,x), \frac{f^{(n+1)}(\xi)}{(n+1)!}(x-a)^{n+1} = \int_{a}^{x} \frac{f^{(n+1)} (t)}{n!} (x-t)^n dt$$

  • Hence,

$$\exists \xi (a,x), R_{n,a} = \frac{f^{(n+1)}(\xi)}{(n+1)!}(x-a)^{n+1}$$

Note:

This doesn't complete the proof. I've assumed here that $$a<x$$.

A similar proof needs to be written for the case $$a>x$$.

The case when $$a=x$$ is rather trivial.

Good Luck for the Exam!

history.subject: Another Nice Proof - The Lagrange Remainder Theorem
history.content:
Well, due to the circumstances, I haven't been able to share any proofs (which, in case you haven't noticed, I like to do).

That said, I'm sharing a simple and pretty relevant proof. 

The Lagrange Remainder Theorem:

Theorem:

  • Let $$I$$ be an open interval. Let $$a\in I$$.
  • Let $$n\in \mathbb{N}$$.
  • Let $$f$$ be a $$C^{n+1}$$ function on $$I$$.
  • Let $$P_n(x)= \sum_{k=0}^{n} \frac{f^{(k)}(a)}{k!} (x-a)^k$$ be its $$n$$-th Taylor Polynomial.
  • Let $$R_n(x)=f(x)-P_n(x)$$ be the remainder.
  • Then

$$\exists \xi \in (a,x), R_n(x)=\frac{f^{(n+1)}(\xi)}{(n+1)!} (x-a)^{n+1}$$

Proof: 

  • Let $$f$$ be a 'smooth curve' defined near $$a$$.
  • Then, using the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, $$\forall x$$ near $$0$$, I can write,

$$f(x)=f(a)+\int_{a}^{x} f'(t) dt$$

  • Use Integration By Parts: $$u=f'(t), du=f''(t)dt, dv=dt, v=t-x$$. Then,

$$f(x)=f(a)+[(t-x)f'(t)]_{t=a}^{t=x} - \int_{a}^{x} f''(t)(t-x)dt$$ 

$$\Rightarrow f(x)=f(a)+(x-a)f'(a) - \int_{a}^{x} f''(t)(t-x)dt$$ 

  • Use Integration By Parts: $$u=f''(t), du=f'''(t)dt, dv=(t-x)dt, v=\frac{(t-x)^2}{2}$$. Then,

$$\Rightarrow f(x)=f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)+ \frac{1}{2} f''(a) (x-a)^2 + \int_{a}^{x} \frac{1}{2} f'''(t) (t-x)^2 dt$$ 

  • After $$n$$ iterations, we get (can be shown rigorously using Induction),

$$f(x)=\sum_{i=0}^{n} \frac{f^{(i)} (a)}{i!} (x-a)^i + \int_{a}^{x} \frac{f^{(n+1)} (t)}{n!} (x-t)^n dt$$

  • The 'Remainder' is:

$$R_{n,a} = f(x)-P_{n,a} =\int_{a}^{x} \frac{f^{(n+1)} (t)}{n!} (x-t)^n dt$$

  • Note: This is the Integral Form of the Remainder.
  • Note: The steps I'm doing from here on can be replaced by the Integral Mean Value Theorem. I'll instead use the steps which are used to prove the IMVT itself.
  • Next, as $$f^{(n+1)}$$ is continuous, by the Extreme Value Theorem, it has both a Max and a Min.
  • Let $$M$$ be the Maximum and $$N$$ be the Minimum of $$f^{(n+1)}$$ on $$[a,x]$$.
  • Then,

$$N \leq f^{(n+1)}(t) \leq M$$

$$\Rightarrow N(x-t)^n \leq f^{(n+1)}(t)(x-t)^n \leq M(x-t)^n$$

$$\Rightarrow \int_{a}^{x} N(x-t)^n \leq \int_{a}^{x} f^{(n+1)}(t)(x-t)^n \leq \int_{a}^{x} M(x-t)^n$$

$$\Rightarrow N \frac{(x-a)^{n+1}}{n+1} \leq \int_{a}^{x} f^{(n+1)}(t)(x-t)^n \leq M \frac{(x-a)^{n+1}}{n+1}$$

$$\Rightarrow N \leq \frac{\int_{a}^{x} f^{(n+1)}(t)(x-t)^n}{\frac{(x-a)^{n+1}}{n+1}} \leq M $$

  • Then, by the Intermediate Value Theorem, as $$f^{(n+1)}$$ is continuous,

$$\exists \xi (a,x), f^{(n+1)}(\xi) = \frac{\int_{a}^{x} f^{(n+1)}(t)(x-t)^n}{\frac{(x-a)^{n+1}}{n+1}}$$

$$\Rightarrow \exists \xi (a,x), \frac{f^{(n+1)}(\xi)}{n+1}(x-a)^{n+1} = \int_{a}^{x} f^{(n+1)}(t)(x-t)^n$$

$$\Rightarrow \exists \xi (a,x), \frac{f^{(n+1)}(\xi)}{(n+1)!}(x-a)^{n+1} = \int_{a}^{x} \frac{f^{(n+1)} (t)}{n!} (x-t)^n dt$$

  • Hence,

$$\exists \xi (a,x), R_{n,a} = \frac{f^{(n+1)}(\xi)}{(n+1)!}(x-a)^{n+1}$$

Note:

This doesn't complete the proof. I've assumed here that $$a<x$$.

A similar proof needs to be written for the case $$a>x$$.

The case when $$a=x$$ is rather trivial.

Good Luck for the Exam!

history.subject: A Question About Taylor Series
history.content:
There are certain questions, both in Problem Set E and Past Exams, which rely upon the uniqueness of Taylor Series. One particular example of such a question is when we are asked to compute the $$N$$-th derivative of a particular function. I believe the 'rigorous' way to solve such a question would be to conduct a comparison of the coefficients of the given 'Taylor Series' with the general expression for the Taylor Series of an arbitrary function centered at $$a$$. Such a comparison can only be conducted if we assume the given function is analytic (which it is, as it can be written as a Taylor Series on some interval centered at $$a$$), and that its Taylor Series is unique. This leads me to ask the following question:

How do I prove that every analytic function has a unique Taylor Series?

children.subject:
Sorry there is a typo.

 

A function can be expanded at different centres. For example, ex can be expanded as $$\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{x^n}{n!}$$ centered at 0, and it can also be expanded as $$\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{e \cdot (x-1)^n}{n!}$$

Are these two series different?
I don't believe so. They're essentially the same Taylor Series, except that they are centered at different points.

history.content:
Just use the definition. 

Given a power series $$S(x) = \sum\limits_{n=0}^\infty b_n (x-a)^n$$, we can immediately write down all of its derivatives at $$a$$: $$S^{(n)}(a) = n! \, b_n$$. From this, we see that we can recover the coefficients of $$S$$ from the values of its derivatives at $$a$$. 

Also, given a $$C^\infty$$ function $$f$$, its Taylor series centred at $$a$$ is by definition a power series that has all the same derivatives as $$f$$ when evaluated at $$a$$. Given that these derivatives also specify the coefficients of the series, there can only be one Taylor series.

children.subject: Actually, I don't really understand the prove provided. Does the proof indicate that interval I is the interval of convergence?

Focus on the statement, not the proof.

The interval $$I$$ has two important features:

1. It is open.

2. $$f$$ is $$C^{n+1}$$ on $$I$$.

Now, there's a different way to look at the element $$a$$.  The theorem's statement might better be interpreted in the following way:

"Choose a point $$a$$ in the domain of $$f$$. Let $$n \in \mathbb{N}$$.
Assume the function $$f$$ is $$C^{n+1}$$ on an open interval $$I$$ containing $$a$$.
Then, for all $$x \in I$$, there exists $$\xi$$ between $$x$$ and $$a$$ such that  ... "

It's the same statement but with a different way of thinking about the relationship between $$a, f,$$ and $$I$$.

history.content:
Maybe I'm not sure what you're asking. The theorem says that $$I$$ is an open interval containing $$a$$, and it's where $$f$$ is defined.

That's what it is. It's the place where all the stuff in the theorem is happening. $$x$$ is given to be the domain of $$f$$, and it's therefore also the domain of the polynomial and the remainder. 

The theorem makes no claims about that being the interval of convergence of anything. The theorem doesn't even actually say anything about a power series. Lagrange's remainder theorem is about Taylor polynomials. Nothing in this theorem has an interval of convergence.

history.subject: TT1 Q2b revisited
history.content:
Hi, 

Can anyone help me check if my justification for why G(x) is continuous at -6 is correct.
Thanks!

As you wrote in the beginning, we need the limit to be equal to the value of the function, which means that your final goal is to show  $$\displaystyle \lim_{x \to -6^-} G(x)=\displaystyle \lim_{x \to -6^+} G(x)=G(-6)$$. The easiest way to do this is probably to break into 3 separate cases (i.e., to compute both one-sided limits and the value of the function separately).

For one of the one-sided limits (the one that you end up computing), your justification looks very good: the Squeeze Theorem is a very good approach. But it isn't clear that that's a one-sided limit -- please make that a bit more explicit so it's easier to follow! Then don't forget to also compute the other side-limit separately. 

For the computation of $$G(-6)$$, we do kind of care about $$H(-6)$$: to have $$0 (H(-6))=0$$, we would just need to be sure that $$H(-6)$$ is a finite number (although, indeed, its specific value is not important and it is enough to notice that $$-6 \in dom(H)$$). Also, you can actually compute $$H(-6)$$ without much work! Plug in $$-6$$ directly and see what $$H$$ does there: you care about the behaviour of the function only at this one very, very specific $$x$$-value.

Does this help?

history.subject: Uniqueness of Taylor series
history.content:
Hi,
I know there are some posts about this question, but I am still confused after reading the posts.

My confusion is about the fact that:
"IF f(x) can be represented as a power series at a, THEN that power series must be Taylor series at a."

We can get the power series that represents the function by manipulating the series of an analytic function.  However, why the power series that we get is the Taylor series. In other words, why when we are trying to find a series that represents a function, we can say that the Taylor series is the only possible power series if the function is analytic.

The Taylor series and any other power series have the same n'th derivatives at all orders hence the coefficients are the same, and two power series are equal if and only if they have the same coefficients on every term.
Two power series are equal if and only if they have the same coefficients on every term, so the coefficients for h are the same as those for the Taylor series.

If f is an analytic function, and g is the Taylor series for f centered at a, then f=g. If h is some other power series that equals f (and hence also equals g) then we know that g(a)=h(a), so they have the same constant term. Furthermore since g=h then g'(a)=h'(a), so they have the same linear coefficient. Furthermore since g=h then g''(a)=h''(a) so they have the same quadratic term. Furthermore since g=h then g'''(a)=h'''(a) so they have the same cubic term. Furthermore since......


Another way to see this is that two power series are equal if and only if they have the same coefficients on every term, so the coefficients for h are the same as those for the Taylor series.

If f is an analytic function, and g is the Taylor series for f centered at a, then f=g. If h is some other power series that equals f (and hence also equals g) then we know that g(a)=h(a), so they have the same constant term. Furthermore since g=h then g'(a)=h'(a), so they have the same linear coefficient. Furthermore since g=h then g''(a)=h''(a) so they have the same quadratic term. Furthermore since g=h then g'''(a)=h'''(a) so they have the same cubic term. Furthermore since......

children.subject:
To clarify how we get the relationship f(x) = S(x) (Taylor series) = P(x)(a power series),  does you mean that since we know the derivative, sum, antiderivative of an analytic function is analytic then we know there must exist such a Taylor series that S(x) = f(x) and after manipulating the analytic function we have f(x) = P(x)? Then we have f(x) = S(x) (Taylor series) = P(x)(a power series). 

From another aspect, when we want to represent a function as a Taylor series, we first try to write the Taylor series by definition and prove the function is analytic. If the function is not analytic, then we've proven that the Taylor series we wrote can't represent the function (ie: f(x) != S(x)). However, why we can conclude that there is no other power series that can represent the function?

1) I would recommend you look up the difference between a Power Series and Taylor Series. Will be helpful.

2) Your question is answered by the definition of the Taylor Series. Remember, the formula we arrived at in order to write out the Taylor Series of a function follows directly from the other two definitions. Moreover, this means that if, by using the formula, we do not arrive at a Taylor Series which is equal to the corresponding function, i.e. prove that the function is not analytic, it follows that either of the first two definitions can also not be satisfied (ofcourse, if one is satisfied, the other is also satisfied). In short, the answer lies in the equivalent of the three definitions. Therefore, once we have written out a potential Taylor Series, and shown the the function is not analytic, it follows tha there cannot exist another Power Series which will be equal to the function, as, by definition, the only such Power Series which can equal the function was found not to.

If we want to solve the limit $$\lim_{x \rightarrow 0}\dfrac{\sin x}{x}$$ using L'Hoptial's rule, it violates the second point of the hypothesis. 

But I am pretty sure that we can use the theorem for this limit.

Can someone please explain this to me? I am really really confused.
The second point says that g and g' are never zero near $$0$$, and in your case g=x. So it asks that x and 1 are never zero near $$0$$. This seems to be true
The second point says that g and g' are never zero, and in your case g=x. So it asks that x and 1 are never zero. This seems to be true

children.subject:
I think you might be a bit confused by the wording in the theorem. It says that g and g' are never 0 as x-> a. Notice that x and 1 are never equal to 0 as x->0. x does indeed limit to 0 as x->0, but it never equals 0. If it was a function that crossed the x axis infinitely many times as you get close to 0, then you wouldn't be able to use that, because for some values of x, it would be literally equal to 0.

This confused me a lot too when I first saw it, but I'm pretty sure the explanation I gave is the right way to think about it

This is correct. The theorem requires that $$g(x)$$ and $$g'(x)$$ are not 0 in a small interval around $$a$$ (i.e $$(a - \delta, a) \cup (a, a + \delta)$$). Otherwise what happens is you get a quotient that is also undefined or poorly defined near $$a$$ and you can't talk about the limit at all.
